awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Constraining the flux of magma and magmatic CO2 during early-stage rifting in East Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
Identifying and quantifying the key ingredients for rift initiation and evolution is fundamental to our understanding of plate tectonic theory, revealing how extensional plate boundaries initiate and develop in order to break apart continents. Two of these ingredients, magma and magmatic volatiles, play not only a critical role in continent break up, but also the growth of continental crust and atmospheric evolution. Critically, rates of magmatism and related magmatic degassing are poorly constrained for continental rifts on Earth, and thus the primary focus of this study is to quantify the flux of magma and magmatic volatiles during the initial stages of continental rifting. In addition to constraining these fundamental parameters, outcomes of this project will include refining annual estimates of natural carbon dioxide emissions, quantifying rates of magma recharge into hazardous volcanoes, and advancing our understanding of subsurface fluid movement in areas of geothermal energy potential. The outcomes of this project can also inform earthquake models by better constraining processes of fluid movements along faults, potentially leading to advances in earthquake hazard forecasts. 

To answer these questions, new measurements of field-based gas flux and carbon isotopes analyses of magmatic CO2 will be collected along and across the rift axis of the East African Rift. Target areas include the Manyara, Natron, and Magadi rift basins near the Kenya-Tanzania border, which range in age from 1 to 7 Ma. By comparing rift basins of different ages, we will illuminate along-axis changes in volatile degassing at different stages of rift development through time. An important goal is to place these findings in context with existing observations (e.g., geophysical, geochemical, geodetic) of key rifting processes to identify spatial links between volatile flux, tectonic deformation, magma intrusion, and volcanism. Field, geochemical, and geophysical observations will then be compared and contrasted with thermal-petrographic model simulations of tectonic extension and magmatic processes (e.g., intrusion, cooling, crystallization, and degassing). Numerical modeling scenarios will be constrained by, and tested against, the full range of observational datasets in the region, including: (1) newly acquired CO2 data, (2) sub-crustal magma bodies inferred from existing 2-D and 3-D geophysical models, (3) chemistry and phase equilibria of erupted products, (4) thermal state of the crust, and (5) crustal thinning. Comparisons between observations and modeling results will allow us to constrain, for the first time, the plausible range of magma fluxes at various locations and stages of rift development at this type locality for active magmatic rifting.

por.por_cntn:
Although modern human activities currently represent the largest source of CO2 into the atmosphere, Earth's carbon ultimately has origins in the planet's deep interior. The background natural CO2 degassing responsible for previous climate states in Earth's history is primarily released at different tectonic plate boundaries, particularly those associated with volcanic activity (e.g., volcanoes of the Pacific Ring of Fire). At these volcanic settings, carbon stored deep in the Earth is dissolved into magmas as CO2. This magma then ascends upward and either (1) erupts at the surface, were it releases this CO2, or (2) stalls at shallow depths in the crust and releases the CO2 into cracks and faults, which act as pathways for this CO2 to rise to the surface. For the past few decades, investigations into the natural fluxes of carbon to our atmosphere have primarily focused on volcanoes along subduction zones. In contrast to these previous studies, our project examined variations in CO2 fluxes at continental rift systems, by examining magmatism and associated CO2 degassing in the East African Rift System in Tanzania and Kenya. In particular, we addressed how CO2 fluxes vary on the scale of 10s to 100s of km, and how these variations relate to changes in magmatism, crustal deformation, and other deep lithospheric processes.

Or results show that the greatest deep CO2 fluxes occur in rift basin segments that show evidence for recent and ongoing volcanic and magmatic activity. In particular, the Natron (North Tanzania) and Magadi (South Kenya) rift basins show the highest CO2 fluxes (mean values of 46-51 g m2 d-1) at identified regions of deep carbon discharge. The highest recorded fluxes, some exceeding 1000 g m2 d-1, were observed on the active volcano Oldoinyo Lengai in the Natron basin. The rate of CO2 degassing in regions of ongoing magmatism in Natron and Magadi contrasts relatively magma-poor regions to the south, including the Manyara and Balangida basins, which exhibit low fluxes (mean values 4-12 g m2 d-1) at identified regions of CO2 discharge. These results collectively reveal the critical role of deep magmatic processes in liberating deep carbon from the Earth and then releasing it into the atmosphere at continental rift settings.

By comparing results with earthquake data, we observe broad correlations with deep volatile degassing and patterns of earthquake seismicity in our study sites. Persistent and ongoing swarms of earthquakes occur consistently below the Natron basin and are best explained by fluid-driven fracturing during the ascent of CO2-rich fluids along crustal faults and fractures. Our interpretations are further supported by observations of magmatic CO2 degassing at locations where deep faults reach the surface. These results highlight the critical role of deep CO2 for triggering earthquake activity as the CO2 ascends the Earth's crust before releasing into the atmosphere.

Finally, regions of high CO2 flux in North Tanzania and South Kenya coincide with a major boundary in the East African Rift System, where ~200 km-thick Archean lithosphere (>2.5 billion years old) meets younger ~150 km-thick Proterozoic lithosphere (<2.5 billion years old). The presence of this boundary helps to explain the unique and high CO2 fluxes in the Natron and Magadi basins. Indeed, when we compare our surface CO2 flux data with deep geophysical imaging of the Earth, we see that the highest CO2 flux occurs when we cross the boundary from Archean to Proterozoic lithosphere. This observation suggests that deep stores of carbon are likely being stripped from the older Archean lithosphere during continental rifting, and that this carbon likely accumulated over billions of years prior to the activation of the East African Rift System.

In all, our study has provided insights into the mechanisms and sources of deep carbon release, providing new constraints on the fluxes of carbon from continental rifts and the various processes that control these fluxes. By working collectively with partners at the University of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, this project has also provided training and research support for a Tanzanian MSc student. This work highlights the critical role of continental rifts, and the East African Rift System generally, for sourcing Earth's natural atmosphere CO2, and the role of this CO2 in driving deformation and earthquakes in these regions.
